title-group.article-title: Book Review: The epistle to diognetus – edition and studies: G. Aragione, Enrico Norelli, and Flavio G. Nuvolone (eds), A Diognète – Visions chrétiennes face à l’empire romain: Actes de la journée d’étude du GSEP du 24 novembre 2007

article-meta.product: AragioneG. NorelliEnrico NuvoloneFlavio G. (eds), A Diognète – Visions chrétiennes face à l’empire romain: Actes de la journée d’étude du GSEP du 24 novembre 2007 (Cahiers du Groupe suisse d’études patristique 1; Lausanne: Éditions du Zèbre, 2012. €20.00. pp. . ISBN: 978-2-940351-14-5).

body.p: This compact volume provides a useful edition of the text of the Epistle to Diognetus, with Greek text and facing French translation. The brief critical apparatus to the Greek text records various of the variants and emendations that are recorded in the three major transcriptions of the text and some of the most significant critical editions. It is a little surprising to see so little interaction with the important work of Henry Meecham (1949) and the total absence of reference to the edition and brief commentary of E.H. Blakeney (1943). Notwithstanding these omissions, the text and notes are extremely serviceable.

The volume then contains four studies. R. Brändle, ‘Ad Diognetum. Eine Wiederaufnahme paulinischer und johanneischer Theologie am Ausgang des zweiten Jahrhundrets’ (pp. 39-52); H.E. Lona, ‘Die Christen in der Gesellschaft aus der Sicht des Ad Diognetum und des Kelsos’, (pp. 53-78); M. Rizzi, ‘Ad Diognetum 2-4: Polemics and Politics’, (pp. 79-90); and E. Norelli, ‘Ramener l’A Diognète en Asie Mineure? Une discussion de la thèse de Charles E. Hill’, (pp. 91-120). These studies analyze theological, social, political, and academic theories about the Epistle to Diognetus. Regular readers of the Expository Times will recall the Book of the Month review of Charles Hill’s From the Lost Teaching of Polycarp (Exp Times 118.2, Nov. 2006), where Hill argued that Polycarp was the author of the Epistle to Diognetus and that the Epistle was written in Asia Minor. Norelli reviews this hypothesis, but in the end remains unconvinced. Instead he re-asserts his own suggestion that the writing originated in Rome, but he recognizes the points of contact with Alexandria and in particular with Clement. On this basis he has more sympathy with Lona’s proposal of an origin in Alexandria, then that of Hill.

Overall this is a useful addition to the corpus of literature dealing with the Epistle to Diognetus. It will be particularly useful in making the text available in translation to French readers, and as such should be read alongside H.-I. Marrou’s important edition.
